segment.source: Consider how often we read text in our daily lives - in email, a book, a road sign, the prices on a menu, tire pressure markings, or posters on a street pole.
segment.target: Consider how often we read text in our daily lives - in email, a book, a road sign, the prices on a menu, tire pressure markings, or posters on a street pole.

segment.source: Text controls
segment.target: Text controls

segment.source: Text controls
segment.target: Text controls

segment.source: Text controls consist of text input boxes, password boxes, auto-suggest boxes, and text blocks.
segment.target: Text controls consist of text input boxes, password boxes, auto-suggest boxes, and text blocks.

segment.source: The XAML framework provides several controls for rendering, entering, and editing text, and a set of properties for formatting the text.
segment.target: The XAML framework provides several controls for rendering, entering, and editing text, and a set of properties for formatting the text.

segment.source: The controls for displaying read-only text are TextBlock and RichTextBlock.
segment.target: The controls for displaying read-only text are TextBlock and RichTextBlock.

segment.source: The controls for text entry and editing are: TextBox, AutoSuggestBox, PasswordBox, and RichEditBox.
segment.target: The controls for text entry and editing are: TextBox, AutoSuggestBox, PasswordBox, and RichEditBox.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: AutoSuggestBox class
segment.target: AutoSuggestBox class

segment.source: PasswordBox class
segment.target: PasswordBox class

segment.source: RichEditBox class
segment.target: RichEditBox class

segment.source: RichTextBlock class
segment.target: RichTextBlock class

segment.source: TextBlock class
segment.target: TextBlock class

segment.source: TextBox class
segment.target: TextBox class

segment.source: Is this the right control?
segment.target: Is this the right control?

segment.source: The text control you use depends on your scenario.
segment.target: The text control you use depends on your scenario.

segment.source: Use this info to pick the right text control to use in your app.
segment.target: Use this info to pick the right text control to use in your app.

segment.source: Render read-only text
segment.target: Render read-only text

segment.source: Use a TextBlock to display most read-only text in your app.
segment.target: Use a TextBlock to display most read-only text in your app.

segment.source: You can use it to display single-line or multi-line text, inline hyperlinks, and text with formatting like bold, italic, or underlined.
segment.target: You can use it to display single-line or multi-line text, inline hyperlinks, and text with formatting like bold, italic, or underlined.

segment.source: TextBlock is typically easier to use and provides better text rendering performance than RichTextBlock, so it's preferred for most app UI text.
segment.target: TextBlock is typically easier to use and provides better text rendering performance than RichTextBlock, so it's preferred for most app UI text.

segment.source: You can easily access and use text from a TextBlock in your app by getting the value of the Text property.
segment.target: You can easily access and use text from a TextBlock in your app by getting the value of the Text property.

segment.source: It also provides many of the same formatting options for customizing how your text is rendered.
segment.target: It also provides many of the same formatting options for customizing how your text is rendered.

segment.source: Although you can put line breaks in the text, TextBlock is designed to display a single paragraph and doesn’t support text indentation.
segment.target: Although you can put line breaks in the text, TextBlock is designed to display a single paragraph and doesn’t support text indentation.

segment.source: Use a RichTextBlock when you need support for multiple paragraphs, multi-column text or other complex text layouts, or inline UI elements like images.
segment.target: Use a RichTextBlock when you need support for multiple paragraphs, multi-column text or other complex text layouts, or inline UI elements like images.

segment.source: RichTextBlock provides several features for advanced text layout.
segment.target: RichTextBlock provides several features for advanced text layout.

segment.source: The content property of RichTextBlock is the Blocks property, which supports paragraph based text via the Paragraph element.
segment.target: The content property of RichTextBlock is the Blocks property, which supports paragraph based text via the Paragraph element.

segment.source: It doesn't have a Text property that you can use to easily access the control's text content in your app.
segment.target: It doesn't have a Text property that you can use to easily access the control's text content in your app.

segment.source: Text input
segment.target: Text input

segment.source: Use a TextBox control to let a user enter and edit unformatted text, such as in a form.
segment.target: Use a TextBox control to let a user enter and edit unformatted text, such as in a form.

segment.source: You can use the Text property to get and set the text in a TextBox.
segment.target: You can use the Text property to get and set the text in a TextBox.

segment.source: You can make a TextBox read-only, but this should be a temporary, conditional state.
segment.target: You can make a TextBox read-only, but this should be a temporary, conditional state.

segment.source: If the text is never editable, consider using a TextBlock instead.
segment.target: If the text is never editable, consider using a TextBlock instead.

segment.source: Use a PasswordBox control to collect a password or other private data, such as a Social Security number.
segment.target: Use a PasswordBox control to collect a password or other private data, such as a Social Security number.

segment.source: A password box is a text input box that conceals the characters typed in it for the sake of privacy.
segment.target: A password box is a text input box that conceals the characters typed in it for the sake of privacy.

segment.source: A password box looks like a text input box, except that it renders bullets in place of the text that has been entered.
segment.target: A password box looks like a text input box, except that it renders bullets in place of the text that has been entered.

segment.source: The bullet character can be customized.
segment.target: The bullet character can be customized.

segment.source: Use an AutoSuggestBox control to show the user a list of suggestions to choose from as they type.
segment.target: Use an AutoSuggestBox control to show the user a list of suggestions to choose from as they type.

segment.source: An auto-suggest box is a text entry box that triggers a list of basic search suggestions.
segment.target: An auto-suggest box is a text entry box that triggers a list of basic search suggestions.

segment.source: Suggested terms can draw from a combination of popular search terms and historical user-entered terms.
segment.target: Suggested terms can draw from a combination of popular search terms and historical user-entered terms.

segment.source: You should also use an AutoSuggestBox control to implement a search box.
segment.target: You should also use an AutoSuggestBox control to implement a search box.

segment.source: Use a RichEditBox to display and edit text files.
segment.target: Use a RichEditBox to display and edit text files.

segment.source: You don't use a RichEditBox to get user input into you app the way you use other standard text input boxes.
segment.target: You don't use a RichEditBox to get user input into you app the way you use other standard text input boxes.

segment.source: Rather, you use it to work with text files that are separate from your app.
segment.target: Rather, you use it to work with text files that are separate from your app.

segment.source: You typically save text entered into a RichEditBox to a .rtf file.
segment.target: You typically save text entered into a RichEditBox to a .rtf file.

segment.source: Is text input the best option?
segment.target: Is text input the best option?

segment.source: There are many ways you can get user input in your app.
segment.target: There are many ways you can get user input in your app.

segment.source: These questions will help answer whether one of the standard text input boxes or another control is the best fit for getting user input.
segment.target: These questions will help answer whether one of the standard text input boxes or another control is the best fit for getting user input.

segment.source: Is it practical to efficiently enumerate all valid values?
segment.target: Is it practical to efficiently enumerate all valid values?

segment.source: If so, consider using one of the selection controls, such as a check box, drop-down list, list box, radio button, slider, toggle switch, date picker, or time picker.
segment.target: If so, consider using one of the selection controls, such as a check box, drop-down list, list box, radio button, slider, toggle switch, date picker, or time picker.

segment.source: Is there a fairly small set of valid values?
segment.target: Is there a fairly small set of valid values?

segment.source: If so, consider a drop-down list or a list box, especially if the values are more than a few characters long.
segment.target: If so, consider a drop-down list or a list box, especially if the values are more than a few characters long.

segment.source: Is the valid data completely unconstrained?
segment.target: Is the valid data completely unconstrained?

segment.source: Or is the valid data only constrained by format (constrained length or character types)?
segment.target: Or is the valid data only constrained by format (constrained length or character types)?

segment.source: If so, use a text input control.
segment.target: If so, use a text input control.

segment.source: You can limit the number of characters that can be entered, and you can validate the format in your app code.
segment.target: You can limit the number of characters that can be entered, and you can validate the format in your app code.

segment.source: Does the value represent a data type that has a specialized common control?
segment.target: Does the value represent a data type that has a specialized common control?

segment.source: If so, use the appropriate control instead of a text input control.
segment.target: If so, use the appropriate control instead of a text input control.

segment.source: For example, use a DatePicker instead of a text input control to accept a date entry.
segment.target: For example, use a DatePicker instead of a text input control to accept a date entry.

segment.source: If the data is strictly numeric:
segment.target: If the data is strictly numeric:

segment.source: Is the value being entered approximate and/or relative to another quantity on the same page?
segment.target: Is the value being entered approximate and/or relative to another quantity on the same page?

segment.source: If so, use a slider.
segment.target: If so, use a slider.

segment.source: Would the user benefit from instant feedback on the effect of setting changes?
segment.target: Would the user benefit from instant feedback on the effect of setting changes?

segment.source: If so, use a slider, possibly with an accompanying control.
segment.target: If so, use a slider, possibly with an accompanying control.

segment.source: Is the value entered likely to be adjusted after the result is observed, such as with volume or screen brightness?
segment.target: Is the value entered likely to be adjusted after the result is observed, such as with volume or screen brightness?

segment.source: If so, use a slider.
segment.target: If so, use a slider.

segment.source: Choose the right keyboard for your text control
segment.target: Choose the right keyboard for your text control

segment.source: Applies to: TextBox, PasswordBox RichEditBox
segment.target: Applies to: TextBox, PasswordBox RichEditBox

segment.source: To help users to enter data using the touch keyboard, or Soft Input Panel (SIP), you can set the input scope of the text control to match the kind of data the user is expected to enter.
segment.target: To help users to enter data using the touch keyboard, or Soft Input Panel (SIP), you can set the input scope of the text control to match the kind of data the user is expected to enter.

segment.source: Tip This info applies only to the SIP.
segment.target: Tip This info applies only to the SIP.

segment.source: It does not apply to hardware keyboards or the On-Screen Keyboard available in the Windows Ease of Access options.
segment.target: It does not apply to hardware keyboards or the On-Screen Keyboard available in the Windows Ease of Access options.

segment.source: The touch keyboard can be used for text entry when your app runs on a device with a touch screen.
segment.target: The touch keyboard can be used for text entry when your app runs on a device with a touch screen.

segment.source: The touch keyboard is invoked when the user taps on an editable input field, such as a TextBox or RichEditBox.
segment.target: The touch keyboard is invoked when the user taps on an editable input field, such as a TextBox or RichEditBox.

segment.source: You can make it much faster and easier for users to enter data in your app by setting the input scope of the text control to match the kind of data you expect the user to enter.
segment.target: You can make it much faster and easier for users to enter data in your app by setting the input scope of the text control to match the kind of data you expect the user to enter.

segment.source: The input scope provides a hint to the system about the type of text input expected by the control so the system can provide a specialized touch keyboard layout for the input type.
segment.target: The input scope provides a hint to the system about the type of text input expected by the control so the system can provide a specialized touch keyboard layout for the input type.

segment.source: For example, if a text box is used only to enter a 4-digit PIN, set the InputScope property to Number.
segment.target: For example, if a text box is used only to enter a 4-digit PIN, set the InputScope property to Number.

segment.source: This tells the system to show the number keypad layout, which makes it easier for the user to enter the PIN.
segment.target: This tells the system to show the number keypad layout, which makes it easier for the user to enter the PIN.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The input scope does not cause any input validation to be performed, and does not prevent the user from providing any input through a hardware keyboard or other input device.
segment.target: The input scope does not cause any input validation to be performed, and does not prevent the user from providing any input through a hardware keyboard or other input device.

segment.source: You are still responsible for validating the input in your code as needed.
segment.target: You are still responsible for validating the input in your code as needed.

segment.source: For more info, see Use input scope to change the touch keyboard.
segment.target: For more info, see Use input scope to change the touch keyboard.

segment.source: Color fonts
segment.target: Color fonts

segment.source: Applies to: TextBlock, RichTextBlock, TextBox, RichEditBox
segment.target: Applies to: TextBlock, RichTextBlock, TextBox, RichEditBox

segment.source: Windows has the ability for fonts to include multiple colored layers for each glyph.
segment.target: Windows has the ability for fonts to include multiple colored layers for each glyph.

segment.source: For example, the Segoe UI Emoji font defines color versions of the Emoticon and other Emoji characters.
segment.target: For example, the Segoe UI Emoji font defines color versions of the Emoticon and other Emoji characters.

segment.source: The standard and rich text controls support display color fonts.
segment.target: The standard and rich text controls support display color fonts.

segment.source: By default, the IsColorFontEnabled property is true and fonts with these additional layers are rendered in color.
segment.target: By default, the IsColorFontEnabled property is true and fonts with these additional layers are rendered in color.

segment.source: The default color font on the system is Segoe UI Emoji and the controls will fall back to this font to display the glyphs in color.
segment.target: The default color font on the system is Segoe UI Emoji and the controls will fall back to this font to display the glyphs in color.

segment.source: The rendered text looks like this:
segment.target: The rendered text looks like this:

segment.source: Text block with color font
segment.target: Text block with color font

segment.source: For more info, see the IsColorFontEnabled property.
segment.target: For more info, see the IsColorFontEnabled property.

segment.source: Guidelines for line and paragraph separators
segment.target: Guidelines for line and paragraph separators

segment.source: Applies to: TextBlock, RichTextBlock, multi-line TextBox, RichEditBox
segment.target: Applies to: TextBlock, RichTextBlock, multi-line TextBox, RichEditBox

segment.source: Use the line separator character (0x2028) and the paragraph separator character (0x2029) to divide plain text.
segment.target: Use the line separator character (0x2028) and the paragraph separator character (0x2029) to divide plain text.

segment.source: A new line is begun after each line separator.
segment.target: A new line is begun after each line separator.

segment.source: A new paragraph is begun after each paragraph separator.
segment.target: A new paragraph is begun after each paragraph separator.

segment.source: It isn't necessary to start the first line or paragraph in a file with these characters or to end the last line or paragraph with them; doing so indicates that there is an empty line or paragraph in that location.
segment.target: It isn't necessary to start the first line or paragraph in a file with these characters or to end the last line or paragraph with them; doing so indicates that there is an empty line or paragraph in that location.

segment.source: Your app can use the line separator to indicate an unconditional end of line.
segment.target: Your app can use the line separator to indicate an unconditional end of line.

segment.source: However, line separators do not correspond to the separate carriage return and linefeed characters, or to a combination of these characters.
segment.target: However, line separators do not correspond to the separate carriage return and linefeed characters, or to a combination of these characters.

segment.source: Line separators must be processed separately from carriage return and linefeed characters.
segment.target: Line separators must be processed separately from carriage return and linefeed characters.

segment.source: Your app can insert a paragraph separator between paragraphs of text.
segment.target: Your app can insert a paragraph separator between paragraphs of text.

segment.source: Use of this separator allows creation of plain text files that can be formatted with different line widths on different operating systems.
segment.target: Use of this separator allows creation of plain text files that can be formatted with different line widths on different operating systems.

segment.source: The target system can ignore any line separators and break paragraphs only at the paragraph separators.
segment.target: The target system can ignore any line separators and break paragraphs only at the paragraph separators.

segment.source: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.
segment.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
segment.target: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
